statement.tex: \text{From a lot of 15 bulbs which includes}\\ \text{5 defectives, a sample of 4 bulbs is drawn}\\ \text{one by one with replacement. Find the}\\ \text{probability distribution of number of defective}\\ \text{bulbs. Hence find the mean of the distribution.}

\\ \text{In the table below, }\textit{d = defective bulb}\text{ and }\\ \textit{ok = non-defective bulb.}\\ \textbf{But what are the probabilities A-E?}\\ \begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|} \hline N & \text{Example Sequence} & P(n=N) \\ \hline 0 & \lbrace ok,ok,ok,ok\rbrace & A \\ \hline 1 & \lbrace ok,d,ok,ok \rbrace & B \\ \hline 2 & \lbrace ok,d,d,ok \rbrace & C \\ \hline 3 & \lbrace d,ok,d,d \rbrace & D \\ \hline 4 & \lbrace d,d,d,d \rbrace & E \\ \hline \end{tabular}
\\ \text{Given the probability distribution in Step 1,}\\ \text{what is the }\textbf{mean of the distribution?}

reason.tex: \text{If p = probability of drawn bub being defective}\\ \text{and q = probability of it not being defective,} \\ \text{then }p=\frac{5}{15} = \frac{1}{3}\text{ and }q = 1-p=\frac{2}{3}.\\ \textbf{Remember, the bulbs are drawn with }\\ \textbf{replacement}\text{ (they are put back once drawn).}\\ \begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|} \hline N & \text{Example Sequence} & P(n=N) \\ \hline 0 & \lbrace ok,ok,ok,ok\rbrace & ^4C_0\cdot p^0q^4 =\frac{16}{81} \\ \hline 1 & \lbrace ok,d,ok,ok \rbrace & ^4C_1\cdot p^1q^3=\frac{32}{81} \\ \hline 2 & \lbrace ok,d,d,ok \rbrace & ^4C_2\cdot p^2q^2 =\frac{8}{27} \\ \hline 3 & \lbrace d,ok,d,d \rbrace & ^4C_3\cdot p^3q = \frac{8}{81} \\ \hline 4 & \lbrace d,d,d,d \rbrace & ^4C_4\cdot p^4q^0 =\frac{1}{81} \\ \hline \end{tabular}

\text{The mean - or the expected value - E(x) is}\\ \text{given by the following}\\ \begin{align} E(x) &= \sum_{n=1}^N n\cdot P(n) \\ \therefore E(x) &= \left[0\cdot \frac{16}{81} + 1\cdot\frac{32}{81} + 2\cdot \frac{8}{27} + 3\cdot \frac{8}{81} + 4\cdot \frac{1}{81} \right] \\ &= \dfrac{4}{3} \end{align} \\ \text{What this means is that if one were to draw}\\ \text{4 bulbs with replacement many times over }\\ \text{and count the number of defectives drawn,}\\ \text{then the average over all those rounds of }\\ \text{drawing would be }\frac{4}{3}.
